Good morning, I'm up early, feeling a bit nervous and excited about today's writing day. I've quit working on my previous novel, North, and I'm starting a new one today. I'm a bit sad to let go of the old project, but I think it's the right decision. I've made progress on the new novel, crafting my theme, identifying the central conflict, and starting on world building mechanics. I'm excited to continue working on this story and dive into drafting. I had a good day with Kirsty, and I'm looking forward to a cozy evening watching TV and relaxing. I'm feeling a bit worn out, but I'm excited about this new project and can't wait to make progress on it.

Hello everyone, I'm Z from transvoicelessons.com. In this video, I'll be sharing my voice evolution from masculine to feminine over the course of five and a half years. I've documented my progress with audio files, and we'll be listening to them in chronological order.  My journey began in 2010 when I started studying music composition. I graduated in 2015 and began my transition, which included changing my voice. The first clip we'll listen to is from March 25th, 2015, when I hadn't even started practicing my voice yet. My voice was very deep and masculine.  Two months later, I came out and started practicing my voice more realistically. The next clip is from May 25th, 2015, and it's my first attempt at a feminine voice. However, I was over-abducting and bringing my false folds in, resulting in a high-pitched and airy sound.  As I continued to practice, I made progress, but I still struggled with finding the right way to achieve thinness with my voice. I was getting closer, but I was still making common beginner mistakes, such as over-abducting and having poor vocal fold closure.  Around July 30th, 2015, I was getting ready to start touring with my band, and I kind of gave up on voice practice for a while. However, I eventually picked it up again and continued to work on my transition.  Over the next 10 months, I made significant progress, and my voice started to sound more feminine. I still didn't have hormones yet, but I was working on my voice and transition. We'll be listening to more clips from this time period, and I'll be sharing my thoughts on what I was doing right and wrong.

I'm a 14-year-old trans boy who's been on puberty blockers since I was 9. I'm excited to start testosterone soon and feel like I'm falling behind my friends who are developing facial hair. I've been open about my transition at school and have received support from my friends and family. I'm looking forward to top surgery and being able to be myself without any restrictions.  I've been to the Museum of Transology with my friend E-Jane, who's a trans woman. We saw exhibits on trans lives, including hormone treatments and binders. I was excited to see the collection of objects and stories from trans people.  I'm proud of myself for coming out at 9 and for being open about my transition. I wish I had done it earlier, but I'm grateful for the support I've received. I'm excited for the future and for being part of a positive trans community.  I want to encourage others who are scared or struggling to come out and be themselves. It's the best thing for yourself, even if it's hard. There are people who will support you, and it's a weight lifted off your shoulders.

The Last Airbender's enduring popularity can be attributed to its character-driven storytelling. The show's well-rounded and developed characters, their relationships, and emotional growth are what make it timeless. The emotional impact of scenes, such as Zuko's apology to Iroh and the final fight between Zuko and Azula, stick with viewers long after they've forgotten the show's intricate details.  The show's ability to capture the human experience through its characters' flaws and relatable emotions is key to its success. The scene where Toph and Sokka almost die on the airship is a prime example of this, as it showcases the culmination of their growth and trust in each other. The show's focus on people and their connections, rather than just plot or action, is what gives it a strong emotional impact and makes it a good story regardless of the decade.  The Last Airbender's character-driven approach is what sets it apart from other shows and makes it relatable to audiences. The show's ability to balance action, world-building, and emotional depth is a testament to its creators' skill and dedication to storytelling. The show's themes of growth, trust, and redemption are timeless and continue to resonate with viewers today.

Uncle Iroh is a beloved character in Avatar: The Last Airbender, known for his wisdom, compassion, and dedication to his nephew Zuko. His character development throughout the series is a key factor in his memorability. Initially, Iroh appears as a laid-back uncle, but as the series progresses, his backstory and motivations are revealed, adding depth to his character.  Two pivotal moments in the series showcase Iroh's emotional impact: his memorial for his deceased son Lu Ten in the "Tales of Ba Sing Se" episode and his reunion with Zuko at the end of Book 3. In the first moment, Iroh's actions are recontextualized as a way to make amends for his inability to help his son, highlighting his selflessness and love for his family.  The second moment, Iroh's reunion with Zuko, is a heartwarming display of forgiveness and love. Iroh's actions demonstrate that he sees Zuko as a reflection of himself, having also been a product of the Fire Nation's propaganda and hatred. Iroh's travels after his son's death humanized people outside of the Fire Nation and allowed him to incorporate aspects of different nations into himself, making him a more well-rounded and empathetic character.  Iroh's connection to the spirit world and his ability to see Aang in his spirit form further illustrate his unique perspective and connection to the world. His character serves as a reminder of the importance of compassion, forgiveness, and understanding, making him a beloved and memorable character in the series.

Hello, I'm Dara Hoffman Fox, and I'm reading from my book, You and Your Gender Identity, A Guide to Discovery. In chapter three, we're discussing how to take a positive approach to your fears. If you believe in the power of the mind to change a negative to a positive, try these tips:  1. Remember why you're doing this: You're transitioning to improve your life, not become less happy. Reflect on your logline, which reminds you of your goal to move towards happiness and contentment.  2. Focus on positive outcomes: Imagine your life several years after embarking on your gender identity journey. Think about the positive changes that could occur and list at least five.  3. Expose yourself to positive narratives: Pay attention to the types of content you consume on social media. Keep track of how many posts, tweets, or messages leave you feeling better versus worse. Remove or distance yourself from sources that make you feel worse.  By taking these steps, you can gain control over the messages you receive and increase your exposure to positive influences. This can help you feel more empowered and hopeful, which is essential for overcoming fear.

The Last Airbender features complex characters with interesting parallels, particularly between Katara and Azula. At first glance, they seem like vastly different characters, but upon closer inspection, their lives diverged due to their upbringing and how they dealt with their mother's death. Both characters lost their mothers at a young age, but their fathers handled the situation differently. Ozai, Azula's father, encouraged her to hate her mother, Ursa, while Katara's father, Hakoda, raised her in a supportive household where she knew her mother loved her.  Azula's upbringing led her down a path of violence and aggression, while Katara's encouraged her to be kind and nurturing. Katara felt pressure to be maternal due to her mother's absence, while Azula was emotionally manipulated into becoming a weapon for Ozai. Their relationships with their siblings also differed, with Azula being pitted against Zuko by Ozai, while Katara and Sokka had a healthier relationship.  The environment in which someone grows up can have a significant impact on who they become. Katara's upbringing allowed her to express her emotions and cope with her mother's loss, while Azula's inability to do so led to her downfall. Azula's inability to process her emotions and deal with her trauma led to her mental instability and eventual defeat by Katara.  The contrast between Katara and Azula's characters serves as a reminder that people's behavior is often shaped by their environment and upbringing. It's essential to recognize how someone's upbringings can drive them in a certain direction, and to offer them the support they need to become better versions of themselves.

Hello everyone, welcome back to my channel. Today, I'm going to discuss why I think Zuko's redemption arc in Avatar: The Last Airbender is so successful. There are three key reasons why his story works so well.   Firstly, his redemption is not linear. Zuko's path doesn't just go straight from bad to good. He has setbacks and moments where he reverts to his old ways, making his eventual change more believable and satisfying. This is a realistic portrayal of growth and change, as most people don't change overnight.   Secondly, Zuko's story comes full circle. He returns to the Fire Nation and gets everything he ever wanted, but it's not what he expected. He realizes that the life he was chasing was not what he truly wanted, and this leads to a lot of internal anguish for him. This is a crucial part of his development, as it allows him to see the error of his ways and make amends.  Lastly, Zuko knows that people will hate him and accepts that without getting defensive. He doesn't try to shift the responsibility for his actions elsewhere or expect people to forgive him easily. Instead, he earns their trust by putting in the work and being willing to make amends. This is a key part of his redemption arc, as it shows that he's truly committed to changing his ways.  These three reasons make Zuko's redemption arc so satisfying and relatable. It's a blueprint for how anyone can try to be good once they realize they're on the wrong side. If you liked this video, be sure to subscribe and consider supporting me on Patreon. Thank you for watching, and I'll see you next time.

The video discusses the importance of realistic and casual queer representation in media, using the TV show Brooklyn Nine-Nine as an example. The show's portrayal of its queer characters, particularly Rosa Diaz and Captain Holt, is praised for being authentic and relatable. The video highlights how the show's writers have avoided stereotypes and instead focused on developing the characters' personalities and relationships beyond their queerness.  Rosa's storyline is particularly notable, as she is given space to date women and talk about her relationships in a natural way. Her girlfriend, Jocelyn, is introduced and becomes a part of the show, with their relationship facing ups and downs just like any other couple. The video praises the show's ability to balance Rosa's queerness with her other personality traits and storylines.  Captain Holt and his husband Kevin are also highlighted as a great example of queer representation. Despite not sharing an on-screen kiss, their relationship is shown to be loving and affectionate, with moments of tenderness and humor. The video notes that their relationship is portrayed in a way that feels genuine and authentic, with a focus on their personalities and interactions rather than their queerness.  The video concludes by emphasizing the importance of casual queer representation in media, where queerness is not the sole focus of a character's storyline but rather a natural part of their life. This approach is seen as more realistic and relatable, and the video encourages creators to follow Brooklyn Nine-Nine's example in portraying queer characters in a authentic and respectful way.

Hello everyone, I'm Lewis, also known as Mr Loser. Recently, I wrote an article for Buzzfeed about things trans men are tired of hearing, including the question "how do you have sex?" While some people suggested I should educate people on the answer, I believe it's not productive to ask such personal questions to someone you barely know. However, I'm willing to share my personal experience.  As a trans man, I've had surgery, but not everyone has. It's impossible to generalize how all trans people have sex. When I first started dating my girlfriend, she was nervous about it, but I realized that was normal. She had only been with non-trans guys before and didn't know what to expect. I've had testosterone treatment, which caused my clitoris to grow into a small penis. Even before surgery, I saw that part of me as male.  I've had a metoidioplasty, a type of lower surgery that works with what's already there. While it's not the biggest, it looks natural. Sex is even better with my girlfriend now because I'm more comfortable with myself. However, it hasn't made a massive difference to our sex life. I believe that when you really like someone, you look past their physicality.  I hope this video has helped you understand sex with or as a trans guy. If you have any further questions, please comment below. Thank you for watching, and don't forget to like and subscribe if you're feeling kind.

Hello everyone, I'm Z from Trans Voice Lessons. I wanted to give you an update on what's been going on with me and the channel.   Firstly, I've been dealing with some health issues since July and August, which caused me a lot of pain and discomfort. However, after changing my diet and lifestyle, I've managed to get most of my symptoms under control.   Unfortunately, just as I was getting back on track, the wildfires in Oregon started, and the air quality became unbearable. I had to evacuate my home and stay in a hotel for a few days, which set me back on my work.   Despite the challenges, I'm excited to announce that I've found a new apprentice, Nick, who's an agender individual with a lot of experience in singing and voice alteration. We're working together to create a 12-week intensive voice feminization class, which will be an online course with 12 sessions.   This class will allow us to reach more people, increase availability, and bring the cost down. We're also planning to create webinars and other group lesson environments to meet the demand of our students.   Additionally, I've been working on a glossary of terms to help my viewers understand the terminology used in voice alteration. I'll be sharing this glossary with you all soon.   I want to thank you all for your support and understanding during this time. I'm looking forward to getting back to creating content and working with all of you.   In summary, my health is improving, I have a new instructor, we're launching a voice class, creating webinars, and I've made a glossary of terms for you all. Thank you for watching, and I'll see you in the next video.

Living with chronic pain and disabilities can be incredibly challenging. The speaker has Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), a condition that affects their joints, muscles, and overall mobility. They experience pain and discomfort when performing everyday tasks, such as lifting objects, walking, or even holding their phone. The pain is often invisible to others, making it difficult for them to communicate their struggles.  The speaker uses a power chair, cane, and sometimes walks short distances, but each of these activities comes with its own set of challenges. They experience pain, fatigue, and dizziness, which can be triggered by various factors, including hot temperatures, standing for too long, or even getting up too quickly.  The speaker highlights the importance of understanding and accepting disabilities, rather than making assumptions or judgments based on appearance. They encourage viewers to be more aware of the invisible struggles that people with disabilities face and to be more considerate and respectful.  The speaker also shares their personal experiences with ableism, including receiving hurtful comments and experiencing accessibility barriers. They emphasize the need for greater understanding and acceptance of disabilities, rather than trying to "fix" or "cure" them.  Ultimately, the speaker's message is one of empowerment and self-acceptance. They encourage viewers to be more aware of their own biases and to be more considerate of the struggles that people with disabilities face. Having a beard was a significant aspect of my transition, especially in the early stages. I was obsessed with checking my face daily for new hair growth after starting testosterone. A full beard developed after about a year, and it became an integral part of my identity. However, now at 25, I'm considering shaving it off for a few reasons.   Firstly, I'm curious to see how my face looks without the beard, as it's been the most noticeable change since starting hormones. I'm also interested in experiencing the sensation of having smooth skin and watching it grow back.   Lastly, with upcoming acting auditions, I want to have the option to show people how I look with and without the beard. I'll have my girlfriend take headshots of me without the beard to see if I can pass as younger. I'm a bit scared but have decided to go through with it.

The Southern Raiders episode in Book 3 of Avatar The Last Airbender is a side story that features Katara and Zuko. While it's not crucial to the main plot, it provides valuable insight into Katara's backstory and character development. The episode explores Katara's desire for revenge against the person who killed her mother, which is connected to her distrust of Zuko due to his past betrayal.   Through this storyline, the show reveals a new side of Katara, showcasing her anger and hatred, and her ability to bloodbend. The episode also raises a moral dilemma about whether Katara should kill the person who killed her mother, and her decision not to do so is a significant moment in her character development.   The Southern Raiders episode has a lasting impact on the main storyline, as it affects Katara's relationship with Zuko and sets the stage for Aang's future battles. The episode is well-integrated into the overall storyline, providing new information about Katara's backstory and deepening the relationships between main characters.   In contrast, other episodes, such as Nightmares and Daydreams, may feel more like filler, as they don't reveal new information about the characters or advance the plot in a significant way. The Southern Raiders episode sets a good example for what makes a side story feel solid and meaningful, and it's a testament to the show's ability to create engaging and impactful storylines.

Toph Beifong is a crucial character in Avatar: The Last Airbender, and her earthbending skills played a significant role in saving the world. As Aang's earthbending teacher, Toph taught him the element that was the most difficult for him to learn, requiring a complete change in his way of thinking and approaching conflict. Without Toph's instruction, Aang may not have learned earthbending at all.  Toph's earthbending skills saved Aang's life in several instances, including when he faced off against Azula and Ozai. Her instruction allowed Aang to learn the rock armor technique, which protected him from Ozai's firebending. Additionally, Toph taught Aang the earthbending ability to sense attacks from behind, which saved his life when Ozai tried to attack him from behind.  Toph's metalbending skills also played a crucial role in the series, as she dismantled the Fire Nation airships using her unique ability. Her skills allowed her to take down the airships and their super-powered firebenders, saving countless lives.  In conclusion, Toph's earthbending and metalbending skills, as well as her teaching abilities, were instrumental in saving the world from the Fire Nation's war. Her contributions to the series are undeniable, making her one of the best characters in Avatar: The Last Airbender.

Hello everyone, today we're going to talk about the single most important element of vocal feminization: R1, or the first vocal tract resonance. Every object around us produces a natural frequency, and our throat has its own pitch, which is like a pipe that produces different frequencies depending on its size. By controlling this throat tone, we can control R1, which acts like a gender knob.  R1 exists as a separate and independent pitch from the one produced by our vocal folds. The distance between these two pitches is the primary factor responsible for determining vocal sex. When we talk or sing, R1 is no longer audible as a clear pitch, but it affects the sound by creating a loud spot and changing the volume of nearby sounds.  To control R1, we need to think of our resonances as modifiers. We can use exercises to explore R1, such as mimicking the sound "eh" with different resonance, modifying the sound "part" to change the R1, using the sound "M" to shrink or expand the R1, and creating vowel gradients to incrementally make the sound brighter.  These exercises should be treated as tools to teach us the general movement and feeling associated with altering R1. It's not about grinding or repeating the exercises without understanding why, but about precisely moving around and gaining new awareness of what we can control.  The fundamental challenge of voice feminization is learning how to create, stabilize, and maintain a higher R1 during speech without any harsh effects. To achieve this, we need to avoid straining, over-tensing, protruding our jaw, or flipping into falsetto.  In summary, R1 is not a place, feeling, or magic, but how cavities and chambers interact with sounds and cause them to change. By understanding and controlling R1, we can gain control over our vocal feminization and achieve a more feminine sound.

Hello everyone, I'm Z from transvoicelessons.com. Today, I'll share a simple trick to help you hear yourself better. When you talk, your voice bounces off the room, creating reverberation. To truly understand how you sound to others, you need to experience this reverb.   To achieve this, place your hands in a specific position: one hand presses against your jaw and cheekbone to dampen vibrations, while the other hand amplifies late reflections from the back wall. This setup blocks early reflections, giving you a more realistic model of your voice in a real space.  This method is more effective than recording or listening to yourself back while talking. Try it now and share your thoughts in the comments. This technique has helped many people feel more confident in their voice practice routines. If you have any questions or comments, please post below.

Embarking on the journey to discover your gender identity can be a challenging and overwhelming experience.  Fear plays a significant role in this process, often stemming from repressed thoughts and feelings that we've been taught to be ashamed of.  Our unconscious mind helps us push these aspects down, locking them away in a "trunk" in our psyche.  This trunk contains secrets and memories that we may or may not remember creating, and it's likely that there's something in it that needs to be looked at.  The presence of fear means we're getting closer to discovering something about ourselves, as we often fear the unknown.  In stage two reflection, we'll explore when we first felt conflicted about our gender identity, what happened, and why we had to put those thoughts and feelings into the trunk.  To begin, let's reach into the trunk and nudge that secret just a little bit, by writing down our thoughts and feelings.

Hello, I'm Dara Hoffman Fox, and I'm reading from my book, You and Your Gender Identity. In chapter three, we're discussing being kinder to yourself on your gender identity journey. Negative messages about gender can create self-loathing and shame, which fear feeds upon. To minimize this, practice self-care by putting your self-care checklist to work. Find at least one activity a day that brings you comfort and balance.  Cut down on excessive escapism, which can become distractions and avoidance techniques. Identify activities on your checklist that might be used for avoidance and cut back on them gradually. Start by reducing the time spent on these activities by 15-30 minutes. Explore alternative activities that engage different parts of your mind and senses.  Create a nurturer, a person or animal that provides you with comfort and support. Imagine your ideal nurturer and how they would help you. This can be a powerful tool for reducing stress and anxiety. Remember, self-care is essential for your well-being, and you deserve to be treated with care, compassion, and love.  To practice self-care, try the following:  - Put your self-care checklist to work and find at least one activity a day that brings you comfort and balance. - Cut down on excessive escapism by reducing the time spent on distracting activities. - Create a nurturer, a person or animal that provides you with comfort and support. - Prioritize self-care and make it a regular part of your life.  By following these steps, you can cultivate a more compassionate and supportive relationship with yourself, which is essential for navigating your gender identity journey.

Hello, I'm Dara Hoffman Fox, and I'm reading my book, "You and Your Gender Identity, A Guide to Discovery." Today, we're discussing Chapter 3, "Feeling the Fear and Doing It Anyway."   Your fear will be with you throughout this journey, and it's essential to understand and work with it. Think of your fears as unwanted guests in your home; they won't leave, so you need to develop a plan to deal with them. By examining the root of your fears, you'll shift from feeling controlled by them to being in control.  To work with your fear, imagine a personal bodyguard who's always by your side when you feel threatened. This bodyguard is a manifestation of your fear, and it's trying to protect you from harm. However, this protection can be overbearing, leading to stunted growth and repression.  To develop a relationship with your bodyguard, start a dialogue with it whenever your fear surfaces. Thank it for being there, remind it that you can get through this together, and ask it to continue to let you know when it thinks you're in danger. Encourage it to understand your point of view and listen to its perspective as well.  For example, imagine having a conversation with your bodyguard, Jules, about getting a tattoo. Jules expresses concern, but you reassure it that you're ready for this step and that you'll always need its protection. By dialoguing with your bodyguard, you can learn more about the roots of your fear and develop a more nuanced understanding of yourself.  Remember, your bodyguard is not the enemy; it's a part of you that's trying to protect you. By working with it, you can overcome your fears and move closer to the truth about your gender identity.

Hello, I'm Dara Hoffman Fox, and I'm continuing to read from my book, You and Your Gender Identity, A Guide to Discovery.  Today, we're discussing the exercise "Setting Appointment Times with Your Fears" from chapter three, Feeling the Fear and Doing It Anyway.   This exercise helps you acknowledge and manage your fears during your gender identity journey by creating a plan to keep them from overwhelming you. You'll set boundaries with your fears by scheduling appointments with them, giving you control instead of letting them control you.  To do this exercise, follow these steps:  1. Identify when your fears arrive (times of day, situations that trigger them). 2. Choose a place to meet your fears (e.g., car, home, nature, cafe). 3. Decide on the duration of each appointment (start with 5-10 minutes). 4. Determine how many times per day you'll meet with your fears. 5. Choose a method to keep track of your appointments (e.g., notebook, phone, computer). 6. Schedule your appointments and jot down any unexpected fears that arise. 7. Practice self-care before each appointment (e.g., meditation, deep breathing). 8. Start the clock and immerse yourself in the dialogue with your fear. 9. Let the appointment begin and engage with your fear until the timer goes off. 10. Practice self-care after the appointment to signify its end.  By following these steps, you'll reduce the distraction caused by your fears and put yourself in the driver's seat to address them. In the next video, we'll discuss taking a positive approach to your fears.

Today, I watched the 2007 animated movie Battle for Terra. The movie is set on a planet called Terra, where humans are trying to colonize and the native aliens, called Terrarians, are fighting back. The villain is a human military leader who wants to eliminate the Terrarians by any means necessary. The main character, Mala, is a Terrarian inventor who befriends a human soldier, Jim, and helps him understand their culture.  The movie has a star-studded cast, including Evan Rachel Wood, Luke Wilson, and Danny Trejo. The CGI is not great, but it's passable, and the animation of the Terrarians is fluid and well-rendered. The movie also explores themes of xenophobia, colonization, and the consequences of war.  One of the pros of the movie is that it's free to watch on YouTube, and it's a unique take on the space movie genre. However, there are some cons, such as the lack of dialogue in the first 15-20 minutes, the underdeveloped human characters, and the lack of expression on their faces.  The movie also has some plot holes, such as why Mala needs to create a flying contraption when she can already float. Additionally, the humans' motivations for going to war with the Terrarians are unclear, and the movie's metaphors about colonization and xenophobia are not fully developed.  Overall, I gave the movie a 6.5 out of 10, which is my first half-point score. I liked it more than I liked the perfect score, but I didn't like it quite as much as I liked Cellular. The IMDb score is 6.6, and the Rotten Tomatoes score is 5.52. I would watch it again if someone I knew had the need to watch it, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it again.

If you're struggling with isolation, this video is for you. As someone who has spent most of their life at home due to chronic illness and inaccessibility, I've learned ways to lift my spirits and continue personal growth. Finding small joys is key. For me, it's enjoying a cup of hot coffee, watching the sunrise, or listening to musical theater.  To stay engaged, create a schedule or allow for unstructured time. Write down things that bring you joy and put them in a bowl to pick from when you're feeling restless. Self-discovery is also an opportunity during alone time. Reflect on your actions, behaviors, and thoughts to understand yourself better.  Self-therapy is essential, especially when professional help isn't available. Keep an eye on your mental health, question your thoughts, and find healthy ways to cope. I've practiced mirror work, exposure therapy, and correcting intrusive thoughts, which have helped me manage my mental illnesses.  Grieving the life you once had is a common experience, especially during pandemic lockdowns or chronic illness. Allow yourself to feel your emotions, and remember that it's not the end. We can find new ways to adapt and continue working, learning, and connecting with others.  My grief is multi-layered, as I've had to grieve not only my ability to go out but also my body's loss of abilities and the loss of privilege. I hope that the tools used by disabled people for accessibility will continue to be popularized and pursued for equitable accessibility for all.  Remember to be kind to yourself and others, especially during this time of collective trauma. Try not to take small outbursts personally, set clear boundaries, and keep yourself safe. Share things that bring you joy and uplift you in the comments.

The Good Place finale was a masterclass in storytelling, leaving viewers emotionally invested and satisfied. A key driver in its success was knowing when to end the show, allowing the writers to give each character a fitting send-off. The show's four-season run allowed for a concise and impactful conclusion, unlike shows that are dragged on for too long, losing their emotional core.  The finale's internal conflict, where the protagonists have won and are reflecting on their journey, added depth and meaning. Every main character received nuanced emotional resolution, wrapping up their storylines in a satisfying way. The show's unique premise, where characters can choose when to move on from the afterlife, allowed for a cosmic happily ever after, giving the story a sense of finality.  The finale's bittersweet tone, where characters say goodbye to each other and to the audience, drew viewers into the story and kept them emotionally invested. The show's ending, where the characters cease to exist, is a rare and satisfying conclusion, leaving no room for future storylines or sequels.  The combination of great storytelling techniques, including knowing when to end the show, turning conflict internal, giving emotional resolution, and providing a cosmic happily ever after, made the Good Place finale a unique and satisfying experience. The show's creators deserve credit for crafting a story that has left a lasting impact on viewers.

I'm Rantasmo, and I'm here to talk about Chuck Tingle, a renowned author of surreal, self-published queer erotica. His work, known as Tinglers, features people having sex with anthropomorphized things, such as dinosaurs, unicorns, and Bigfoot. Tingle's unique persona on Twitter and podcasts has gained a massive following, with a distinctive vernacular that's uniquely his own.  While Chuck Tingle's work may seem bizarre, it's not entirely singular. The genres of erotica he writes about, such as dinosaur erotica, predate his literary debut. However, what sets Tingle's work apart is its ethos of inclusivity and acceptance, which has developed over the years. His stories now feature a diverse range of characters, including racial minorities, lesbians, bisexual, and transgender representation.  Chuck Tingle's philosophy is centered around proving love is real, and his work is a satirical extension of a prevalent human desire to explore power dynamics and alienation. His stories often feature characters having sex with monsters, which can be seen as a way to explore these themes. Despite its absurdity, Tingle's work has a beauty to it, imagining a world where everything is capable of love.  In a year that has been tough, Chuck Tingle's work offers a unique perspective on love and acceptance. His stories are a reminder that love is real, and that everyone, everything, and every concept is intrinsically capable of it.

They initially consider episodes like "The Tales of Ba Sing Se" and the finale episodes, but ultimately decide that the Firebending Masters episode is the best. Here are the reasons why:  1. **Worldbuilding and Backstory**: The Firebending Masters episode expands on the Avatar universe, introducing new cultures, traditions, and people. It also provides backstory on Toph and Iroh, and reveals new information about how people used to learn bending long ago.  2. **Aang and Zuko Parallels**: The episode ties together the parallel stories of Aang and Zuko, who are set up as having their destinies intertwined. They both learn firebending together, and their contrasting personalities create a fun and wholesome dynamic.  3. **Contrasting Personalities**: Aang and Zuko's opposing personalities make for great character interactions, and their banter and moments of vulnerability are some of the best in the series.  4. **Driving the Main Plot**: The Firebending Masters episode drives the main plot forward by helping Aang master firebending and Zuko learn the true meaning of firebending, which is crucial for their respective storylines.  Overall, the speaker believes that the Firebending Masters episode is the best non-finale episode of Avatar because it excels in worldbuilding, character development, and driving the plot forward.

Content warning: assault, transphobia, hate crime, gaslighting, and photos of physical harm.  Anna Montgomery, a 20-year-old trans woman, was assaulted in a Belfast restaurant while sitting at a table with her boyfriend. The police are investigating it as a transphobic hate crime. This incident highlights the current transphobic hysteria in the UK, fueled by prominent figures like J.K. Rowling.  Rowling's latest book, Trouble Blood, features a cross-dressing serial killer, perpetuating the narrative that trans women are a threat to cis women and children. This is not new; her earlier book, The Silkworm, also depicted a trans woman as a threat. The Silence of the Lambs, a 1992 film, also perpetuated transphobic narratives.  The trans community has become more visible in recent years, and with that, transphobic hate crimes have increased. In 2016, anti-trans hate crime rose by 81%. A 2019 report by Stonewall estimated that two in five trans people had experienced a hate crime or incident in the past year.  Rowling's response to criticism has been to frame it as an act of oppression, using her platform to silence critics. This has contributed to a culture of transphobia, where people are emboldened to attack trans individuals. The incident with Anna Montgomery is not an isolated event but a result of the cumulative effect of transphobic narratives.  By arguing that trans women are a danger to women and children, people like Rowling have contributed to a culture of violence. Targeted attacks on trans people cannot be treated as isolated incidents; they are a result of the ideas that people like Rowling have attempted to normalize.  To address this issue, we need to tackle the root cause of transphobia in the UK media. Until then, we will see more assaults like Anna's.

Violence is a complex and multifaceted concept that goes beyond physical harm. The World Health Organization defines violence as the intentional use of physical force or power, threatened or actual, against oneself, another person, or a group or community, resulting in or having a high likelihood of resulting in injury, death, psychological harm, maldevelopment, or deprivation.  There are various forms of violence, including physical, psychological, economic, informational, social, political, and sexual. Economic violence can manifest as withholding access to finances, limiting access to basic needs, or wage slavery. Informational violence can be seen in denying education, particularly in areas such as reproductive health, gender, and relationship education.  Social violence can include acts like corporal punishment, segregation, and community pressure. Political violence can be carried out by governing bodies, such as laws and policies that strip certain groups of their human and civil rights. Sexual violence is the violation of one's control over their sexual autonomy.  The WHO's definition of violence is intentionally broad to capture the various forms of harm that can occur. Critics argue that this definition is too broad, but the author counters that this is a way to avoid scrutiny and justify certain actions.  Violence can be justified in certain situations, such as self-defense, anti-colonial resistance, and in the context of policing. However, the level of justification required is high, and violence can become a duty when greater harm is threatened against innocent parties.  In conclusion, violence is a complex and multifaceted concept that requires a nuanced understanding. By recognizing the various forms of violence and the ways in which they can manifest, we can work towards creating a more just and equitable society.

Hello everyone, I'm Kat, and today I want to discuss JK Rowling's recent tweets about transgender people. She retweeted an article using the phrase "people who menstruate" instead of "women," which she responded to by saying that there used to be a word for those people. She then went on to say that if sex isn't real, there's no same-sex attraction, and that erasing the concept of sex removes the ability for men and women to discuss their lives.  I want to clarify that I'm not angry with JK Rowling, but I do think her comments are transphobic. Transphobia is an outright rejection of a transgender person's identity, and in this case, JK Rowling is rejecting the idea that people who menstruate can be anything other than women.  JK Rowling's comments are not just about semantics; they're about excluding trans people from the conversation. She's saying that people who menstruate are women, which alienates trans folk who experience menstruation but don't identify as women.  I think it's time to move on from this conversation and focus on supporting the trans community. We need to work to deprogram language that excludes trans people and create a more inclusive space for everyone.  I'd love to hear your thoughts on this topic in the comments below. Let's keep the conversation cordial and productive.

They claim trans women pose a threat to cis women, and that the trans community is indoctrinating young people. However, evidence shows that most youth who identify as trans do not receive medical support, and those who do have a 100% persistence rate in pursuing hormone replacement therapy or confirmation surgery.  Former member Amy Dias has come forward, sharing her experience of being groomed and abused by the gender-critical movement. She was approached by well-known names who fed her a narrative that lesbians were under attack by trans people, and she was exploited during a vulnerable time in her life.  The gender-critical movement has been associated with fascism and conservative Christianity, and has been accused of covering up for abuse and silencing discussions about female-led abuse. They have also been linked to the rhetoric of Liz Truss, the current Minister for Women and Equalities, who has made threats of legislative violence towards the trans community.  The movement's tactics include downplaying abuse and using mockery to silence critics. They have also begun throwing around threats of legal action, despite the fact that the article never names who it's talking about. The anti-trans SLAP fund has been set up to support those affected by the movement's actions.

Graham Linehan, a former comedy writer, has re-emerged on Twitter promoting transphobic views. He recently asked for a list of therapists who would be willing to torture children to try and convert them to their assigned sex at birth. This is a form of reparative therapy, which is widely condemned by medical establishments as abusive and harmful.   The Trevor Project survey found that 42% of LGBT+ youth who underwent reparative therapy attempted to commit suicide, compared to 17% who didn't. For trans youth, the number was 57%. Another study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that exposure to gender identity conversion efforts before age 10 was significantly associated with suicidality.  In contrast, the gender-affirmative approach, which allows children to explore their identity with support, has been shown to decrease rates of anxiety and depression to levels equal to those seen in cisgender controls.   The speaker believes that adherence to transphobic torture should result in instant revocation of one's license and sanctions for child abuse. They also call for social media platforms to terminate accounts promoting child abuse. The speaker aims to provide resources to support the affirmation of trans youth and to stand against reparative therapy.

Hello, welcome to my writing vlog. Today, I'm excited to start working on my new novel. I've been preparing for this moment over the past couple of weeks, and I feel like I have a solid plot embryo in place. I've also been experimenting with Garth Nix's drafting method, where he writes his first draft by hand. I'm intrigued by this approach and want to try it out for myself.  I've been listening to The Adventure Zone to help me get into the right mindset, and I'm feeling inspired. I've chosen a rough idea for the first scene, but I still need to figure out some details, such as where the scene takes place and how the main character receives the news that sets the story in motion.  I've also been trying to find the perfect ambient noise mix to help me focus. I've settled on a YouTube video with a calming soundscape, and I'm excited to see how it helps me create a sense of atmosphere for my story.  I've started my first 20-minute writing sprint, and it's been a bit of a challenge to get started. I had to figure out some of the logistics of the scene, but I managed to write a whole page in 20 minutes. It feels weird to be doing a complete first draft again, but I'm trying to remind myself that it's okay to make mistakes and that the goal is to make progress, not perfection.  I'm excited to see where this journey takes me, and I'm looking forward to sharing my progress with you.

I've been threatened by Graham Linehan, a prominent figure with over 608,000 followers, for my video exposing his plans to eradicate trans children. He sent a legal threat, but I've been an online commentator for 11 years and have dealt with similar threats before. My wife, a former lawyer, has helped me understand UK defamation law, which places the burden of proof on the defendant. I've done extensive research and can easily demonstrate the veracity of my statements.  Linehan's actions are effectively child torture, using charity and peer-reviewed sources to justify his views. He's trying to silence me and others who expose his bigotry, but it won't work. I've already seen the Pink News article about his actions removed, and I'm preparing for the worst.  I've noticed that even reserved articles, like those by Raoul Wilde and Hemant Mehta, are being targeted by Linehan. He's trying to silence anyone who reports on his actions, but it's clear that he's scared of scrutiny. He's a misogynist who uses his platform to belittle and silence women, including trans women and those who support them.  Linehan has a history of making unfounded allegations and has even written for the Daily Fail, a far-right paper that's been accused of fascism and misogyny. He's now cozying up with this paper, despite accusing them of sexualizing children. It's clear that he's projecting his own bigotry onto others.  I believe Linehan is a run-of-the-mill misogynist who's using his platform to target marginalized groups. He's trying to intimidate his critics into silence, but it won't work. I have a case, and I'm not alone. Many people are speaking out against his actions, and it's only a matter of time before he's held accountable. The video "If conversion therapy is bad, why is sex reassignment good?" by What Would You Say? is a far-right Christian organization that attacks abortion access and preaches that homosexuality is a sin. The video is in support of Graham Linehan's position on gender identity conversion efforts.   The video starts by attacking same-gender couples, claiming that sex reassignment is equivalent to conversion therapy. However, this is a fabrication, as sex reassignment surgery has shifted towards gender confirmation, and conversion therapy is a different practice that involves forcing a child to deny their gender identity.  The video cites a study that claims 80% of children with gender dysphoria will outgrow it, but this statistic is misleading. The study actually found that 84.2% of children referred to gender identity clinics and supported under the gender-affirmative approach do not seek out further support.   The video also claims that gender affirmation involves giving children artificial hormones and plastic surgery, which is not true. Children may receive fully reversible and safe puberty blockers as they enter puberty, which is a medical necessity.  The video uses visual propaganda and stereotypes to demonize trans people, and the creators of the video ignore the science that shows gender affirmation works and gender identity conversion efforts amount to torture.  Caroline Franzen, a therapist and founder of the Relation Academy, has promoted this video and has used it to defend Graham Linehan's support for gender identity conversion attempts. Franzen has also used the thoroughly debunked Rapid Onset Gender Dysphoria article on her website.  The video and Franzen's actions are a form of transphobia and bigotry, and they can cause harm to the LGBT+ community.

We also watched the second season of Shrill, which I enjoyed, but I don't like how the main character settles for someone who doesn't treat her well. I've found a lot of accounts that I really enjoy, including one about a woman with autism and another about a farm owner who feeds her animals. I know that a lot of people are feeling isolated and alone right now, so I wanted to share some of the things that have been keeping me connected and happy. The Princess is reviewing the movie Dumplin', which is based on the book by Julie Murphy. She has a personal connection to the story, having read the book and listened to the audiobook. The movie follows Willowdean, a young fat girl who enters a beauty pageant to honor her late aunt Lucy, who was her only positive fat role model. The Princess loves the movie for its portrayal of body positivity and self-acceptance, but notes that it deviates from the book in some ways.  She praises the cast, particularly Danielle Macdonald, who plays Willowdean, and Maddie Baillio, who plays Millie. The Princess also appreciates the movie's themes of female friendship and empowerment. However, she notes that the movie could have been stronger if it had included more characters from the book, such as Hannah and Amanda, who are people of color and have disabilities.  The Princess also discusses the movie's production history, noting that it was initially picked up by Disney but was later made independently by Jennifer Aniston and other producers. She believes that this independent production allowed for a more authentic and inclusive portrayal of fat characters.  Overall, The Princess loves the movie and the book, and appreciates how they have helped her to grow and learn about body positivity and self-acceptance. She encourages viewers to watch the movie and read the book, and to support more inclusive and authentic storytelling in the media.
